title: Is British A levels harder than IB? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m going to paraphrase a quote from one of the great contemporary philosophers of our time: Oh look, ANUTHA ONE. This is quite a commonly asked question so I’ll just get right into it. Simply put, you can’t compare them if you’re asking “Which is harder”. Why? Well because they’re two very different curriculum that aim to develop very different students at the end of the 2 years. I personally did IB and I can tell you that QUANTITATIVELY, IB has more work. I mean on top of having 6 subjects to study for, you’ve got coursework for each of those subjects. Tell you what, here’s a link to a similar question that I took a part in answering. You’ll find some detail in there too: Is doing IB as hard as A levels? IB has the 4000 word EE, CAS, Theory of Knowledge and it’s associated workload and much, much more that would turn this answer into a damn novel. Does that necessarily make it harder than A levels? I mean if you’re excellent at time management and balancing your life with work then probably not. However, most IB students aren’t like that and immediately go for an elitist attitude towards other curriculums. Some don’t but believe me there’s a lot of students who would put themselves above AP and A levels students purely because IB has more work. Is that work hard? Again, this depends on who you’re asking. The argument of “A levels vs. AP vs. IB” will always exist because you’ll rarely run into somebody who has done all 3 and can attest to which is harder. Until you run into someone that’s done all three, it’ll be hard to justify which is more difficult. NOW. A levels focuses more on developing students to ‘specialize’ in a certain field of study. It’s rigorous in it’s own right in that it will prepare students ONLY for the study, career, or university major that they have chosen. IB on the other hand focuses on creating a ‘rounded’ student that is equipped with a variety of fundamental skills that are useful at university. Skills like good essay writing with citations, critical thinking, and an ability to take the initiative in any scenario, whether voluntary or academically. So that being said, it’s up to what you prefer. If you ask me, I’d say both are difficult regardless of workload. An IB student will always know what it was like to be an IB student and will have gotten used to the deadlines and coursework. They’ll never know the A level type stress. Similarly, an A level student will only know what it’s like to stress about perfecting their work or study in a narrow range of subjects. They’ll never know the IB stress of having 6 subjects with different types of coursework. They are also seen as equal in the eyes of university admissions officers. So why would you pick one over the other? That’s up to what you want to do in life. Do you know what you want to do at university or seek to excel at only a few subjects? Then A levels is for you. Do you just want to get into university for a course you’ve chosen without any other work? Then A levels will your besties for the nest two years. If it’s developing yourself as a student and learning some useful life skills as well as developing yourself as a rounded student in 6 subjects then IB is for you. If you know you’ll probably be moving country and need a curriculum that will allow you to pick up where you left off no matter where you go, then IB is for you. BUT I DIGRESS. You see that’s what happens when you ask which is harder. You can’t really justify. IB students will say IB and A level students will say A levels. Anyway sorry I dragged that out for so long. Just trying to give you perspective. Look, nothing comes easy in life. Education is a learning curve no matter which curriculum you choose. There will be challenges in both curriculums and university isn’t a walk in the park either. So before I shut my yap because I’m sure you’re bored to tears reading already, I’ll just say this: They are both hard. You’ll learn tons no matter which one you pick and you’ll get your pick at a huge variety of universities no matter which one you do. Aight hope that answers your question. Good luck if you’re deciding on a curriculum and remember. You won’t go wrong with either one.

No, certainty not. Anyone who tells you that doing an A level is harder than an IB subject is wrong. The process of A levels is simpler and less stressful and it is very unlikely you will do 6 A levels. The IB Diploma requires a lot more of you psychologically, and while the content is less for some subjects, the preparation for university is the same. You will likely not struggle with A levels if you enjoy your subjects and work hard to deadlines while the IBD requires you to take subjects you may not like, complete activities you won’t enjoy and spend unreasonable amounts of time on things that don’t matter. You’re well prepared for university but it’s a lot more straining and not helpful if you’re doing an apprenticeship
